title: Election vs the economy: what does the vote mean for the pound, markets and GDP?
text:
The battle over the future of Brexit and the heart of the nation is on: it's general election time.

That means financial markets can expect a rollercoaster ride, the economy could be roiled by political risks and the next five weeks will be dominated by the U-word: uncertainty.

Uncertainty itself is not a new phenomenon, though it seems to have reached unusually high levels in recent years, and played a bigger role in influencing the economy.

The economic policy uncertainty index for the UK, compiled by economists from the Chicago, Northwestern and Stanford universities, shows uncertainty around the Brexit referendum was far higher than at the time of the financial crisis, or the Iraq war.
description: The battle over the future of Brexit and the heart of the nation is on:
